Title:
Canker disease caused by Chrysoporthe doradensis and C.
cubensis on Eucalyptus spp. and Tibouchina sp. in Brazil.
Keywords:
Resistance, Tibouchina granulosa, T. heteromalla,
Beta-tubulin gene.
Abstract:
Chrysoporthe species are known to cause canker on hosts
belonging to the families Myrtaceae and Melastomataceae. Cankers occur
on tree trunks and branches and may reduce growth and lead to plant
death. In this study, the incidence and pathogenicity of C. cubensis and
other species causing canker on Eucalyptus spp., Tibouchina heteromalla
and T. granulosa were examined.The isolates, collected in Maranhão (MA)
and Minas Gerais (MG) in Brazil, were subjected to multilocus analysis
using beta-tubulin and actin. Sequence analysis of the genomic regions
confirmed the presence of C. cubensis and C. doradensis on clones of the
hybrid Eucalyptus grandis x E. urophylla.,T. granulosa, and T.
heteromalla in Brazil. Morphological characterization enabled the
identification of the isolates from both genera, primarily based on
differences in conidial size and shape. Pathogenicity tests proved the
isolates were pathogenic to 10 Eucalyptus clones and Tibouchina plants.
The results obtained may contribute to the knowledge of Chrysoporthe
species causing diseases of woody plants in Brazil. For this reason,
Eucalyptus breeding programs should consider this in screening for
resistance. Furthermore, this is the first report of C. doradensis as a
pathogen on Eucalyptus and T. granulosa, as well as the first record of
C. cubensis on T. heteromalla in Brazil.
